results.http://schema.org/name: 3 Tesla fMRI data on episodic memory of place-object associations (general raw data)

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.http://schema.org/name: What does the retrosplenial cortex do?
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/cite: Vann, S., Aggleton, J. & Maguire, E. What does the retrosplenial cortex do?. Nat Rev Neurosci 10, 792–802 (2009) doi:10.1038/nrn2733

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.http://schema.org/name: Evidence for holistic episodic recollection via hippocampal pattern completion
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/cite: Horner, A.J. et al. Evidence for holistic episodic recollection via hippocampal pattern completion. Nat. Commun. 6:7462 doi: 10.1038/ncomms8462 (2015).

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.http://schema.org/name: Holistic Recollection via Pattern Completion Involves Hippocampal Subfield CA3
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/publications.https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/cite: Grande X, Berron D, Horner AJ, Bisby JA, Düzel E, Burgess N. Holistic Recollection via Pattern Completion Involves Hippocampal Subfield CA3. J Neurosci. 2019;39(41):8100–8111. doi:10.1523/JNEUROSCI.0722-19.2019

results.http://schema.org/description: Episodic memories comprise information from various  domains (e.g. objects and scenes). Previous evidence indicates segregated information processing pathways throughout the brain for object and scene information (e.g. Berron et al., 2019). Upon retrieval, an unimodal cue should be able to reinstate the multimodal representation of the episode via a pattern completion process. Empirical evidence for pattern completion across modalities is sparse, particularly on representational level. Within this project we therefore obtain 3 Tesla functional data to focus on the interplay between medial temporal lobe structures and the retrosplenial cortex as well as within the hippocampal circuitry for the reconstruction of multimodal mnemonic episodes. Enhanced retrosplenial functional activity has been associated with vivid retrieval of scenes (Vann et al., 2009), and the hippocampus has found to be related to holistic recollection via pattern completion (Horner et al., 2015; Grande et al., 2019). The current dataset therefore focusses on the interplay between both regions for successful retrieval of across-domain episodes, based on a unimodal cue via pattern completion. Functional neuroimaging data at 3 Tesla has been obtained at high resolution in 25 younger adults. The participants performed a place – object associative retrieval task, during which they had to encode objects placed in a scene. At retrieval the scene served as unimodal cue to retrieve object information.

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: Within the current project we investigate multimodal integration and retrieval of episodic memories. Episodic memories comprise information from various sensory (e.g. visual and auditory) as well as domain-specific (e.g. objects and scenes) modalities. At encoding the different types of segregately processed information need to be integrated into a coherent representation. Upon retrieval, an unimodal cue should be able to reinstate the multimodal representation of the episode via a pattern completion process. Empirical evidence for pattern completion across modalities as well as the integration and multimodal convergence process is sparse. Within this project we therefore obtain 3 and 7 Tesla functional data to focus on the interplay between medial temporal lobe structures and the retrosplenial cortex as well as within the hippocampal circuitry for successful integration and reconstruction of multimodal mnemonic episodes. Enhanced retrosplenial functional activity has been associated with vivid retrieval of scenes (Vann et al., 2009), and the hippocampus has found to be related to holistic recollection via pattern completion (Horner et al., 2015; Grande et al., 2019). The current dataset therefore focusses on the interplay between both regions for successful retrieval of across-domain episodes, based on a unimodal cue via pattern completion. Functional neuroimaging data at 3 Tesla has been obtained at high resolution in 25 younger adults. The participants performed a place – object associative retrieval task, during which they had to encode objects placed in a scene. At retrieval the scene served as unimodal cue to retrieve object information.
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: Place-object associative memory at 3 Tesla fMRI

results.http://schema.org/name: 3D high resolution SRXTM image data of cortical vasculature of rat brain.

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/parcellation.http://schema.org/name: Waxholm Space rat brain atlas v2

results.http://schema.org/description:
The goal of the study is to produce the first high resolution, 3D reconstruction of the entire macrostructure and vascular system of the rat/mouse brain. To that end synchrotron radiation-based X-ray microscopy images were collected. Then the data is translated into 3D mesh and volumetric models (graph).  
This dataset contains high resolution tiff image array of part of cortical vasculature of the rat brain.  
This dataset is used as an input to computational methods that results in the dataset “Graphical representation of rat cortical vasculature reconstructed from high resolution 3D SRXTM data” ([doi: 10.25493/K243-13K](https://doi.org/10.25493/K243-13K)).﻿

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description:
3-D dataset (z-stack) obtained from absorption-based synchrotron radiation X-ray tomographic microscopy (SRXTM) of cylindrical samples of the rat somatosensory cortex (~2.8mm^3). Optical magnification 20x, isotropic voxel spacing of 700nm, 16-bit grayscale images

Further details:
Reichold, J., Stampanoni, M., Keller, A. L., Buck, A., Jenny, P., and Weber, B. Vascular graph model to simulate the cerebral blood flow in realistic vascular networks. Journal of Cerebral Blood Flow and Metabolism, 29(8):1429‚Äì1443, Aug 2009.

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/parcellation.http://schema.org/name: Allen Mouse Common Coordinate Framework v3 2015

results.http://schema.org/description:
The goal of the study is to produce the first high resolution, 3D reconstruction of the entire macrostructure and vascular system of the mouse brain. To that end previously synchrotron radiation-based X-ray microscopy images were collected. Recently two-photon microscopy images were collected to that end. And we are looking for additional alternative imaging sources. Then this data is translated into 3D mesh and volumetric models (graph).  
This dataset contains tiff image array of part of cortical vasculature of the mouse brain.  
This dataset is used as an input to computational methods that results in the dataset “3D reconstruction of the vascular system of the mouse brain” ([doi: 10.25493/47H2-1HR](https://doi.org/10.25493/47H2-1HR)).

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: For SGA1, the main objective will be to achieve a three dimensional image of the entire vascular system of the mouse brain for the first time. This will be achieved by using light-sheet microscopy and/or synchrotron-radiation based X- ray microscopy. Very big data sets (~ 15 TB per mouse brain) will be generated.
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D image of the entire vascular system of the mouse brain

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/parcellation.http://schema.org/name: Allen Mouse Common Coordinate Framework v3 2015

results.http://schema.org/description:
This dataset describes quantitatively the somatodendritic and axonal structure of individual thalamocortical projection neurons in the thalamic somatic and visual sensory nuclei. The cells in the dataset were labeled using state-of the art viral vectors able to drive massive levels of expression of marker proteins in a neuron after a single transfection event, leaving the rest of the brain unlabeled. This allows the unambiguous visualization /measurement of the entire axonal tree, no matter how large or complex. They are the first visualization of these cells ever reported in mice. Experiments were conducted in vivo in wildtype C57BL76 adult animals and have a low (<5%) success rate. Accurate labeling analysis is extremely labor-intensive, especially for large and widespread-axon cells. The present dataset may thus be viewed as a collection of “archetypal” reference specimens of these neuron populations. The accurate 3D data and measurement of axonal arborizations of thalamocortical neurons provide in this dataset will be re-usable by any scientist developing biologically-based models of local and long range brain circuitry.  
**Embargo status:**
*This dataset is temporarily under embargo. The data will become available for download after the embargo period.*

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: We will produce 3D digital reconstruction and quantification of a significant number (30-40) of individual cells from 4 populations of thalamocorical LRPNs (40 in total), each from a different thalamic nuclei, (two specific/sensory and two multispecific/higher order nuclei), with particular focus on their terminal synaptic site in different cortical layers. We chose thalamocortical cells because of their “hub” position in forebrain networks and because the homogeneity in cellular composition of thalamic nuclei makes it technically easier to obtain a significant number of well-labelled cells of the same axonal type.

results.http://schema.org/description:
The goal of the study is to produce the first high resolution, 3D reconstruction of the entire macrostructure and vascular system of the mouse brain. To that end previously synchrotron radiation-based X-ray microscopy images were collected. Additionally recently two-photon microscopy images were collected. And we are looking for additional alternative imaging sources. Then this data is translated into 3D mesh and volumetric models (graph).  
This dataset contains the model of part of cortical vasculature of the mouse brain as a graph structure (discrete mathematics).  
The data is a derived dataset using computational methods from the dataset “3D imaging of the vascular system of the mouse brain” ([doi: 10.25493/3248-7V](https://doi.org/10.25493/3248-7V)).

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: The 3D image will be translated into a three-dimensional graph. The resulting graph will be used as a spatial scaffold for the   cellular elements and will be the basis for simulating the brain’s energy and oxygen delivery. The vascular network is a key element for T4.2.2.
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstruction of the entire vascular system of the mouse brain

results.http://schema.org/description: 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in the human hippocampal CA1 region using Neurolucida software from 3D confocal stack of images.

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: Pyramidal neurons are key components of the cerebral cortex, where they are the predominant cell type. The structural design of brain circuits depends on the type, number and position of neurons, as well as the synaptic connections that they establish. This project contains quantitative information about several relevant features of pyramidal neurons, such as the extension of their dendritic trees, their branching patterns, and the density of dendritic spines, from which the number of synaptic inputs can be derived. These data have been obtained from the hippocampus of humans (CA1 region). Knowing these structural properties is crucial for building, validating and refining brain models.
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in human hippocampal CA1 region

results.http://schema.org/description:
We have produced 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in the mouse hippocampal CA1 region using Neurolucida software from 3D confocal stack of images. Data from 3D reconstructions will be useful to modeling and integration of anatomical data with functional studies in mouse hippocampus. 

**Embargo status:**
*This dataset is temporarily under embargo. The data will become available for download after the embargo period.*

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description:
3D reconstructions of 50 cells in mouse hippocampal CA1 region
Related milestones: MS1.2.3 Reconstruction of pyramidal neurons  M12
MS1.2.8 Reconstruction of dendritic arbors and dendritic spines of pyramidal neurons M24
Verification: Data released and data quality validated
Related task: Task 1.2.1 The pyramidal neuron in the cerebral cortex of humans and rodents
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstructions of 50 cells in mouse hippocampal CA1 region

results.http://schema.org/description:
We have produced 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in rat hippocampal CA1 region using Neurolucida software from 3D confocal stack of images. Data from 3D reconstructions will be useful to modeling and integration of anatomical data with functional studies in rat hippocampus. 

**Embargo status:** *This dataset is temporarily under embargo. The data will become available for download after the embargo period.*

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description:
3D reconstructions of 50 cells in rat hippocampal CA1 region
Related milestones: MS1.2.3 Reconstruction of pyramidal neurons  M12
MS1.2.8 Reconstruction of dendritic arbors and dendritic spines of pyramidal neurons M24
Verification: Data released and data quality validated
Related task: Task 1.2.1 The pyramidal neuron in the cerebral cortex of humans and rodents
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstructions of 50 cells in rat hippocampal CA1 region

results.http://schema.org/description: 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in the human temporal neocortex in two different individuals (s-idab1 and s-idab2), and in the human neocortex from multiple cortical areas (cingular and frontal) in four different individuals (s-idif6, s-idif10, s-idif12 and s-idif16) was performed using Neurolucida software from 3D confocal stack of images. This dataset involves a total of 217 reconstructed cells: 94 in the temporal cortex, 64 in the cingular cortex and 59 in the frontal cortex.

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description: Pyramidal neurons are key components of the cerebral cortex, where they are the predominant cell type. The structural design of brain circuits depends on the type, number and position of neurons, as well as the synaptic connections that they establish. This project involves quantitative information about several relevant features of pyramidal neurons, such as the extension of their dendritic trees, their branching patterns, and the density of dendritic spines, from which the number of synaptic inputs can be derived. These data have been obtained from the neocortex of humans. Knowing these structural properties is crucial for building, validating and refining brain models.
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstructions of pyramidal cells in human neocortex (temporal, cingulate and frontal)

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/parcellation.http://schema.org/name: Allen Mouse Common Coordinate Framework v3 2015

results.http://schema.org/description:
We have produced 3D reconstructions of pyramidal neurons from the mouse somatosensory cortex across layers II-VI using Neurolucida software from 3D confocal stack of images. Data from 3D reconstructions will be useful to modeling and integration of anatomical data with functional studies in mouse brain. 

**Embargo status:** *This dataset is temporarily under embargo. The data will become available for download after the embargo period.*

https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/description:
3D reconstructions of 300 pyramidal neurons from the mouse somatosensory cortex across layers II-VI
Related milestones: MS1.2.3 Reconstruction of pyramidal neurons  M12
MS1.2.8 Reconstruction of dendritic arbors and dendritic spines of pyramidal neurons M24
Verification: Data released and data quality validated
Related task: Task 1.2.1 The pyramidal neuron in the cerebral cortex of humans and rodents
https://schema.hbp.eu/minds/component.http://schema.org/name: 3D reconstructions of 300 pyramidal neurons from the mouse somatosensory cortex across layers II-VI
